Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Annual Dues Support for IASC and SCAR 2014-2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The Polar Research Board (PRB) of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences serves as the U.S. National Committee to two international organizations: the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC), and the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR). IASC encourages and facilitates cooperation in all aspects of Arctic research and in all areas of the Arctic region, provides scientific input to the Arctic Council and other international policy organizations, and provides seed money to support international science development. SCAR helps lead the international Antarctic science community by implementing new research initiatives, identifying emerging scientific themes, promoting international cooperation and partnerships, and providing scientific advice to the Parties to the Antarctic Treaty and others on issues related to the management and protection of the Antarctic region and the Southern Ocean. The U.S. dues requested leverages in-kind contributions from countries around the world.

Broader impacts:
U.S. support for IASC and SCAR provides opportunities for U.S. scientists to network and develop partnerships with colleagues in other countries. For early career scientists these organizations offer a forum to expand research interests and make new connections. SCAR and IASC?s policy advisory activities help ensure that important policy decisions about managing and protecting these regions are based, at least in part, on sound scientific assessment. International collaboration through SCAR and IASC ?s interdisciplinary, international research activities allows the U.S. to accomplish scientific objectives that would be impossible for single investigators, programs, or countries to do alone and provides opportunities for U.S. scientists that would not otherwise be available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Polar Research Board (PRB) of the U.S. National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine has a mission to advance understanding of the polar regions; foster application of polar science to benefit the public and decision makers; advise U.S. research programs so they are responsive to the needs of the nation; encourage interdisciplinary and cross polar perspectives; and provide a forum for independent discussion of polar issues. The PRB also serves as the U.S. National Committee (USNC) to two international nongovernmental polar science organizations: the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC) and the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR). U.S. annual dues support for these organizations is crucially important for advancing opportunities and interests of the U.S. polar research community, and for assuring continued progress in international-level research and assessment activities.

 

IASC is a non-governmental, international scientific organization. IASC’s mission is to encourage and facilitate cooperation in all aspects of Arctic research, in all countries engaged in Arctic research and in all areas of the Arctic region. Overall, IASC promotes and supports leading-edge multi-disciplinary research in order to foster a greater scientific understanding of the Arctic region and its role in the Earth system. IASC has 23 member countries; members are usually national science organizations covering all fields of arctic research.

 

SCAR is charged with the initiation, promotion and co-ordination of scientific research in Antarctica. SCAR also provides international, independent scientific advice to the Antarctic Treaty system and other bodies. Full Members are those countries with active scientific research programs in Antarctica (currently 30); Union Members are those ICSU scientific unions that have an interest in Antarctic research, (currently 9); and Associate Members are those countries without an independent research program as yet or which are planning a research program in the future (currently 13).

 

The PRB has continued its usual responsibilities as U.S. National Committee to SCAR and IASC, such as facilitating communication and coordination of SCAR and IASC activities in the United States, providing a forum at the PRB meetings to discuss issues of importance to SCAR and IASC, and sharing comments and input on various SCAR and IASC initiatives. The PRB communicates regularly with the Delegates and members of the polar research community on issues of importance in international polar science. PRB also supports SCAR and IASC outreach efforts through emails, newsletter communications, and conference calls.

 

The PRB's role as US National Committee to SCAR and IASC means that we facilitate the participation and leadership of U.S. scientists in international research and assessment activities, which help to build good will, establish relationships, and ensure U.S. visibility in the international scientific community. SCAR and IASC often provide critical input to international policy decisions through the Antarctic Treaty process and through the Arctic Council. Thus our efforts to support these programs can often affect important policy and management decisions.

 

The PRB selects the U.S. Delegates and the members of the U.S. delegation, through which the PRB facilitates U.S. participation in the biennial SCAR meetings and the annual IASC meetings. The U.S. delegates to IASC and SCAR also serve as ex-officio members of the PRB to ensure communication and coordination.

 

Dr. Terry Wilson (Ohio State University) serves as the U.S. Delegate to SCAR. Dr. Wilson also serves as the chief officer for the new Scientific Research Programme Solid Earth Response and Influence on Cryosphere Evolution (SERCE). Dr. Deneb Karentz (University of San Francisco) serves as the alternate U.S. Delegate to SCAR.

 

Dr. Larry Hinzman (University of Alaska Fairbanks) serves as the U.S. Delegate to IASC. Dr. Hinzman also serves as a Vice President of the IASC Executive Committee. Dr. Matthew Druckenmiller (National Snow and Ice Data Center) serves as the alternate U.S. Delegate to IASC.

 

SCAR and IASC maintain websites (http://www.scar.org/ and http://www.iasc.info/, respectively) and also distribute information through Bulletins, newsletters, and reports. For recent comprehensive summaries of recent IASC and SCAR activities and accomplishments, please see the 2017 IASC Bulletin (http://iasc.info/images/media/print/bulletin/Bulletin2017.pdf) and the 2016 SCAR Annual Report (http://scar.org/scar_media/documents/publications/bulletins/Bulletin195.pdf).
